intro: Allium siculum subsp. dioscoridis, commonly known as the Sicilian leek, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its hollow, cylindrical leaves and clustered, pale purple to white flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and is well adapted to dry, rocky soils. Its bulbous stem is used in local cuisines, and it is also valued for its ornamental appeal. The subspecies is distinguished by its specific morphology and geographic distribution compared to other Allium species.
